criteria.name: User Research Validation
criteria.description: IA decisions based on user research (card sorting, tree testing, interviews), not assumptions or opinions.

scale.1: No user research. IA based on stakeholder opinions, org chart, or assumptions about users.
scale.3: Some user research (5-10 participants) but limited scope or informal methods.
scale.5: Rigorous user research: card sorting (15-30 users), tree testing (20-50 users), validated with real users before implementation.

criteria.name: Mental Model Alignment
criteria.description: Navigation matches user mental models and vocabulary, not internal company jargon or org structure.

scale.1: Labels use internal jargon, org chart structure, or vague terms ('Solutions', 'Services'). Users confused.
scale.3: Mix of user-friendly and internal terms. Some alignment with user mental models.
scale.5: Labels match user vocabulary from research. Task-based or user-goal oriented. Clear mental model alignment.

criteria.name: Taxonomy Quality (MECE)
criteria.description: Categories are mutually exclusive, collectively exhaustive. Clear, non-overlapping structure.

scale.1: Categories overlap significantly. Gaps in coverage. Items fit multiple places or nowhere.
scale.3: Mostly MECE but some overlaps or gaps. Most items have clear home.
scale.5: Perfect MECE: every item has exactly one primary home, no gaps, no overlaps. Faceted where appropriate.

criteria.name: Navigation Depth & Breadth
criteria.description: Optimal depth (3-4 levels) and breadth (5-9 items per level). Not too flat or too deep.

scale.1: Too flat (>12 top-level items, overwhelming) OR too deep (>5 levels, users lost). Poor balance.
scale.3: Acceptable depth/breadth but some levels have <3 or >12 items. Room for optimization.
scale.5: Optimal: 3-4 levels deep, 5-9 items per level. Balanced hierarchy, manageable choices at each level.

criteria.name: Information Scent
criteria.description: Clear labels, trigger words, descriptive breadcrumbs guide users. Strong predictive cues.

scale.1: Vague labels ('Resources', 'Other'), no breadcrumbs, users guess. Weak scent.
scale.3: Some clear labels but inconsistent. Breadcrumbs present but could be more descriptive.
scale.5: Strong scent: specific labels, user trigger words, descriptive breadcrumbs, preview text. Users click confidently.

criteria.name: Findability Metrics
criteria.description: Measurable findability: time to find, success rate, search vs browse balance.

scale.1: No metrics tracked. Unknown if users can find content.
scale.3: Some metrics tracked (analytics, basic usability) but incomplete or informal.
scale.5: Comprehensive metrics: tree test ≥70% success, time to find <30 sec (simple) / <2 min (complex), 40-60% search/browse balance.

criteria.name: Tree Testing Validation
criteria.description: Navigation structure validated with tree testing before implementation.

scale.1: No tree testing. Built navigation without validation.
scale.3: Informal tree testing (5-10 users) or partial testing (only some tasks).
scale.5: Rigorous tree testing: 20-50 users, 8-12 tasks, ≥70% success rate, <1.5× directness, iterated based on results.

criteria.name: Multiple Access Paths
criteria.description: Users can find content via navigation, search, filters, tags, related links. Supports different strategies.

scale.1: Only one access method (browse-only or search-only). Single path to content.
scale.3: Two access methods (browse + search) but limited. No filters, tags, or related links.
scale.5: Multiple paths: browse, search, faceted filters, tags, breadcrumbs, related links. Supports searchers and browsers.

criteria.name: Scalability & Evolution
criteria.description: Structure designed for growth. Handles 10× content without breaking. Governance plan exists.

scale.1: Structure works for current size but breaks at scale. No governance. No plan for growth.
scale.3: Some consideration for scale. Ad-hoc governance. Will need significant rework as content grows.
scale.5: Designed for scale: faceted for large sets, versioned taxonomy, governance framework (roles, processes, metrics), evolution plan.

criteria.name: Progressive Disclosure
criteria.description: Starts simple, reveals complexity on-demand. Hub-and-spoke, collapsed sections, tiered navigation.

scale.1: Everything visible at once (overwhelming) OR everything hidden (users can't discover).
scale.3: Some progressive disclosure but inconsistent or incomplete.
scale.5: Well-designed progressive disclosure: hub-and-spoke for guides, collapsed sections for long nav, contextual secondary nav.

E-commerce Navigation.specific_guidance: Use faceted navigation (Category × Price × Brand × Rating). Card sort with 20+ customers to understand grouping preferences. Tree test with 'Find product under $X in Y category' tasks. Track search vs browse ratio (target 40-60% each). Provide multiple paths: browse categories, search, filter, sort.

Documentation IA.specific_guidance: Structure by user tasks ('How do I...?') not features. Hub-and-spoke: 'Getting Started' hub with 5-7 clear entry points. 3-4 levels max. Breadcrumbs show path. Related links for discovery. Search with code snippet results. Tree test with 'Find how to do X' tasks (≥80% success).

Content-Heavy Website.specific_guidance: Start with content audit: inventory all content, identify duplicates/gaps. Open card sort (20-30 users) to discover categories. MECE taxonomy design. Tree test (30-50 users, 10-12 tasks). Plan for 3× content growth. Establish governance: taxonomy owner, quarterly reviews, tag moderation.

SaaS Product Navigation.specific_guidance: Card sort with active users (not stakeholders). Rename internal terms to user language: 'Widgets' → 'Reports', 'Modules' → 'Features'. Task-based labels: 'Create Report', 'Share Dashboard'. Flat structure (2-3 levels). Contextual help. Tree test with 'Where would you do X?' tasks. Iterate until ≥75% success.

Intranet / Knowledge Base.specific_guidance: Content audit: remove 40%+ outdated, merge duplicates. Closed card sort with employees to validate categories. Hybrid approach: browse by department + robust search + best bets for common queries. Metadata schema: author, last updated, audience, content type, tags. Governance: content owners responsible for freshness.

Simple (<100 items, clear structure).specific_guidance: Flat structure (1-2 levels). Simple categories. Informal user research acceptable (10 users). Basic tree test (5 tasks, ≥70% success). Monitor with analytics (bounce rate, time on site).

Standard (100-1000 items, moderate compl.specific_guidance: Card sort (15-20 users). MECE taxonomy (3-4 levels, 5-9 items per level). Tree test (20-30 users, 8-10 tasks, ≥70% success, ≤1.5× directness). Multiple access paths (browse + search). Track findability metrics (time to find, success rate, search/browse ratio).

Complex (>1000 items, high complexity).specific_guidance: Full content audit. Card sort (30 users). Faceted navigation (orthogonal facets). MECE taxonomy + controlled vocabulary. Tree test (50 users, 12 tasks, ≥75% success). Multiple access paths (browse, search, filters, tags, related links). Comprehensive metrics dashboard. Governance framework (taxonomy owner, quarterly reviews, versioning, deprecation process).

common_failure_modes.name: Org Chart Navigation
common_failure_modes.symptom: Navigation structured by company departments (Sales, Marketing, Engineering) not user tasks or mental models.
common_failure_modes.detection: Tree test shows low success (<50%). Users say 'I don't know what department handles this.' Card sort reveals users group differently than org structure.
common_failure_modes.fix: Restructure by user tasks or goals. Card sort with users to discover natural groupings. Rename categories to user-facing labels: 'For Developers' not 'Engineering Department'.

common_failure_modes.name: No User Research
common_failure_modes.symptom: IA designed by stakeholders or designers based on opinions, not user data. 'I think users will understand...'
common_failure_modes.detection: No card sort, tree test, or user interviews conducted. Decisions justified by 'makes sense to me' not data.
common_failure_modes.fix: Conduct card sorting (20-30 users) to understand mental models. Tree test (20-50 users) to validate proposed structure before building. Iterate based on results.

common_failure_modes.name: Too Deep Hierarchy
common_failure_modes.symptom: Navigation 5-6+ levels deep. Users need 6+ clicks to reach content. Users get lost, high abandonment.
common_failure_modes.detection: Tree test shows low directness (>2.5×). Analytics shows high bounce rate on intermediate pages. Users complain 'can't find anything'.
common_failure_modes.fix: Flatten structure: 3-4 levels max. Add faceted filters or search to shortcut hierarchy. Use progressive disclosure (hub-and-spoke) instead of deep nesting.

common_failure_modes.name: Vague Labels
common_failure_modes.symptom: Labels like 'Resources', 'Solutions', 'Services' — users don't know what's inside. Weak information scent.
common_failure_modes.detection: Tree test shows users clicking multiple categories before finding content (low directness). Card sort shows users rename these categories to more specific terms.
common_failure_modes.fix: Use specific, descriptive labels. 'Code Samples' not 'Resources'. 'API Documentation' not 'Solutions'. Test labels with tree testing. Match user vocabulary from card sort.

common_failure_modes.name: Non-MECE Taxonomy
common_failure_modes.symptom: Items fit multiple categories OR don't fit anywhere. Overlap and gaps.
common_failure_modes.detection: Content audit shows many items marked 'belongs in multiple places'. Users confused where to look. Card sort shows weak clustering (<50% agreement).
common_failure_modes.fix: Redesign taxonomy to be mutually exclusive (no overlap) and collectively exhaustive (no gaps). Use faceted classification for items with multiple attributes. One primary location + facets/tags for cross-category access.

common_failure_modes.name: No Tree Testing
common_failure_modes.symptom: Built navigation structure without validating users can find content. Launch reveals users struggle.
common_failure_modes.detection: Live site shows low task success, high bounce rate, users complain 'can't find X'. No pre-launch validation done.
common_failure_modes.fix: Always tree test before building. 20-50 users, 8-12 tasks. Target ≥70% success, ≤1.5× directness. Iterate until targets met. Saves rework post-launch.

common_failure_modes.name: Single Access Path
common_failure_modes.symptom: Only browse (no search) OR only search (no browse). Users with different strategies struggle.
common_failure_modes.detection: Analytics shows 90%+ use search (navigation broken) OR 90%+ browse (search broken). Users complain 'I can't browse' or 'search doesn't work'.
common_failure_modes.fix: Provide multiple paths: browse (navigation), search, faceted filters, tags, breadcrumbs, related links. Support both 'searchers' (know what they want) and 'browsers' (exploring).

common_failure_modes.name: Doesn't Scale
common_failure_modes.symptom: Structure works for 100 items but breaks at 1000. Categories become massive, overwhelming.
common_failure_modes.detection: One category has 60%+ of items. Users complain 'too much content'. Search becomes only viable path.
common_failure_modes.fix: Design for scale upfront. Use faceted navigation for large sets. Split large categories into subcategories. Plan for 10× growth. Establish governance to evolve taxonomy as content grows.

common_failure_modes.name: No Governance
common_failure_modes.symptom: Taxonomy degrades over time. Content in 'Other', empty categories, inconsistent tagging.
common_failure_modes.detection: >10% content in 'Other' or 'Uncategorized'. Empty categories exist. User-generated tags have synonyms, typos, noise.
common_failure_modes.fix: Establish governance framework: taxonomy owner, content owners, quarterly reviews. Monitor metrics (% in 'Other', empty categories, tag quality). Process for adding/removing categories, merging tags.

common_failure_modes.name: No Progressive Disclosure
common_failure_modes.symptom: Everything visible at once (overwhelming mega-menu) OR everything hidden (users can't discover).
common_failure_modes.detection: Users complain 'too much information' (overwhelming) OR 'I didn't know that existed' (hidden). Low engagement with deep content.
common_failure_modes.fix: Progressive disclosure: hub-and-spoke for guides (overview → details), collapsed sections in navigation (expand on click), tiered navigation (primary always visible, secondary contextual).
